items.title: ChatLoopBackOff Episode 60 (​Strimzi)
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content:
<article>Strimzi simplifies the deployment, management, and operation of Apache Kafka on Kubernetes and OpenShift. Its goal is to make Kafka a first-class citizen in the Kubernetes ecosystem, easing the burden of managing complex distributed messaging systems. It provides Kubernetes-native APIs and operators to automate the entire Kafka lifecycle, including cluster provisioning, configuration, scaling, updates, and monitoring. Strimzi enables organizations to run Kafka reliably in cloud-native environments by integrating tightly with Kubernetes tools and practices, such as Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs), persistent storage, and role-based access control (RBAC).

Join Ambassador Arsh Sharma on Thursday, June 5 as he dives in to exploring Strimzi with you!</article>

items.title: Salt stack vs rest of the world
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content: <article>Don't miss out! Join us at our next Flagship Conference: KubeCon + CloudNativeCon events in Hong Kong, China (June 10-11); Tokyo, Japan (June 16-17); Hyderabad, India (August 6-7); Atlanta, US (November 10-13). Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io</article>

items.title: Leveraging OSS for flexible API Observability with Kong and Moesif
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content: <article>Leverage Kong's open-source API gateway and Moesif's analytics to build flexible API observability tailored for AI, capturing complex payloads and model inference data. Discover how to proactively detect issues and optimize AI API performance through customizable pipelines and deep insights.</article>

items.title: Building Cloud Native Agentic Workflows in Healthcare with AutoGen
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content: <article>This session explores the integration of AI agents into preventative healthcare with AutoGen, an open-source agentic AI framework. The solution employs a multi-agent system connected to open-source LLMs such as Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct and DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Llama-70B, hosted with Kubernetes infrastructure, and built on top of the Open Platform for Enterprise AI (OPEA). It streamlines patient data filtering and generates personalized communication. Attendees will gain insight into the architecture of the agentic framework, the OpenAI compatible API and models hosted on cloud servers, and the front-end elements with Streamlit and Hugging Face Spaces. The session will very practically cover how these technologies work together to define screening criteria, filter patient data, and automate the generation of outreach emails.</article>

items.title: ChatLoopBackOff Episode 59 (​OpenCost)
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content:
<article>OpenCost is an incubating CNCF open source project used for measuring and allocating cloud infrastructure and container costs in real time. Built by Kubernetes experts and supported by finops practitioners, OpenCost is a vital tool for operators to understand their Kubernetes spend footprint.

Join CNCF Ambassador Faisal Afzal as he explored OpenCost for the first time.</article>

items.title: ChatLoopBackOff Episode 58 (​Helm)
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content:
<article>A CNCF graduated project since 2020, Helm is an open source package manager for Kubernetes. It provides the ability to provide, share, and use software on clusters. It is a highly customizable tool, and it abstracts the application deployment to a simple configuration file.

Originally created in 2015, Helm is driving into 2025 with plans of a major new version, Helm 4, which has brought in new contributors and users who are passionate about application deployment on Kubernetes.

Join CNCF ambassador Satyam Soni as he explores Helm for the first time.</article>
